comment_text.mn122:1.1: In the discourse, as with the previous, emptiness is associated with physical seclusion and the development of serenity meditation leading to insight.
comment_text.mn122:2.2: The Sakyans Khemaka, known for his dark skin, and Ghaṭā are otherwise unknown. Their “lodges” (vihāra) were, according to the commentary, buildings offered by them for the use of the Saṅgha inside the Banyan Tree Monastery, rather than being their personal homes.
comment_text.mn122:2.3: The fact that they were readily noticeable suggests that the beds were in the open, a detail confirmed by Tibetan parallel. Bedding and furniture were typically property of the Saṅgha, rather than individuals, so it is an offence to leave them exposed to the elements (Bu Pc 14, Bu Pc 15).
comment_text.mn122:2.8: Some translators (Chalmers, Horner, Siam Rath), as well as the Dictionary of Pali Proper Names, take this name as the masculine form ghaṭāya, assuming it is compounded with sakkassa; but names are not usually compounded in this way (cf. kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa above), and ghaṭāya does not seem to be attested elsewhere. In his hand-written manuscript, Ñāṇamoḷī had ghāṭā, which was followed by Bodhi and Thanissaro. This reads the masculine agent noun “slayer”; but the genitive form would be ghātassa, while PTS, BJT, MS, and commentary all have ghaṭāya with no variants. Rather, read per text as the feminine genitive of ghaṭā, suggesting that it was a woman who donated the building. She was perhaps born under the astrological sign known in India as kumbha or ghaṭa (“water-pot”), and in the west as Aquarius (“water-bearer”).
comment_text.mn122:2.15: This the period after the Rains Retreat, when cloth is offered by the lay community at the kaṭhiṇa ceremony, and monastics busy themselves with sewing and repairs before setting out wandering. To this day, it is a time when the pent-up energies of the retreat are relaxed and the Saṅgha gathers for socializing in large numbers.
comment_text.mn122:3.2: This is defined at MN 139:9.18 as the four absorptions.
comment_text.mn122:4.1: The “temporary and pleasant” liberation is the absorptions, while the “irreversible and unshakable” liberation is arahantship.
comment_text.mn122:5.1: Taken in isolation, rūpa here might be “physical form” (i.e. “body”), but in passages with similar phrasing it is “visible form” (i.e. “sight”; AN 1.1:2.1, AN 5.55:3.3).
comment_text.mn122:6.2: Normally the meditations on emptiness and on signlessness are presented as separate meditation practices (SN 41.7:4.1). But in the previous sutta, the meditation on signlessness was presented as one of the stages in the manifestation of emptiness (MN 121:10.1). The outcome of the signless meditation is a heart that is “empty” of greed, hate, and delusion (MN 43:37.1).
comment_text.mn122:6.3: Tittha, literally “ford”, is a path to salvation, used as a term for a non-Buddhist “religion”. Titthakara is a “religious founder” (literally “ford-maker”); titthiya is a “monastic of (another) religion” (for example at Bu NP 22:1.2.5); titthiyasāvaka is a “disciple of a monastic of (another) religion”.
comment_text.mn122:6.4: Compare Sanskrit udyuyuje at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.1.5.7, which likewise concerns withdrawing from a hermit to avoid annoyance. Here, uyyojanika is the causative form, to “send away” or “dispatch”.
comment_text.mn122:9.5: This phrase indicates that they have “situational awareness” (sampajañña), namely a contextual overview of how their meditation is progressing, understood in terms of cause and effect. The phrase also occurs in the same sense at AN 7.49:3.3.
comment_text.mn122:9.8: For imperturbable, see MN 105:12.3. In this mode of practice, they wanted to develop emptiness before the formless attainments. Contrast with MN 121:10.1, where they develop the signless meditation only after the formless attainments.
comment_text.mn122:10.1: Even though they had previously attained up to the fourth absorption, their practice is not yet fully stabilized. | For this phrase, see MN 36:45.6 and AN 6.28:4.3.
comment_text.mn122:10.2: In this context, it seems that “emptiness” is a way of deepening absorption.
comment_text.mn122:11.1: The Buddha goes on to explain who one with such advanced meditation is able to maintain their practice. | The phrase tassa … bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato (“While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation”) sounds like it means they are actually in the meditation state itself, but this passage shows that this is not necessarily the case, as they are able to walk about and hold conversations.
comment_text.mn122:15.7: Even such an advanced meditator might sill have baser desires beneath the surface. However, so long as they are aware of this they do not stray from the path.
comment_text.mn122:17.1: Finally the meditator undertakes discernment (vipassanā).
comment_text.mn122:20.1: Here we find mentioned only the first three of the normal nine categories (aṅga) of the teaching (MN 22:10.2). This may be an earlier list or perhaps simply an abbreviation. Note that the PTS edition reads yadidaṁ suttaṁ geyyaṁ veyyākaraṇassa hetu, which would imply only two categories: “for the sake of explanations, namely statements and mixed prose & verse”. A passage at AN 5.194:3.3 mentions four categories, with the addition of “amazing stories”, but this too might be simply an artifact of abbreviation.
comment_text.mn122:20.3: The Buddha shifts to address Ānanda directly. This is in reference to the fact that Ānanda was renowned as the greatest master of scriptural memorization.
comment_text.mn122:20.4: That is, rather than simply memorizing more texts, one such as Ānanda should seek encouragement that supports practice.
comment_text.mn122:22.1: As is made clear by the example of the spiritual practitioner below, who is said to follow the Buddha, the “tutor” (ācariya, or satthā “teacher” in the next line) and the “pupil” (antevāsī) here are outside of Buddhism.
comment_text.mn122:22.3: The more a monastic has a reputation for seclusion, the more people seek them out.
comment_text.mn122:27.1: This passage seems to mean, “I shall not work you …”, which is the exact opposite of the sense required by the next sentence. A Sanskrit parallel yields the required sense with the verb dhanayiṣye, “to treasure, to mollycoddle” (Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya, Kd 17:493). Perhaps an initial negatory a- has been elided in the Pali parakkamissāmi, which would yield a similar sense, “I shall not stop working you …”. | The same Sanskrit passage has bhājanānā (“pots”) where the Pali has āmake āmakamatte, literally “uncooked, a bit damp”.

root_text.mn122:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ nigrodhārāme.
root_text.mn122:2.1: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kapilavatthuṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn122:2.2: Kapilavatthusmiṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāro tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
root_text.mn122:2.3: Tena kho pana samayena kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāre sambahulāni senāsanāni paññattāni honti.
root_text.mn122:2.4: Addasā kho bhagavā kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāre sambahulāni senāsanāni paññattāni.
root_text.mn122:2.6: “sambahulāni kho kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāre senāsanāni paññattāni.
root_text.mn122:2.7: Sambahulā nu kho idha bhikkhū viharantī”ti.
root_text.mn122:2.8: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ ghaṭāya sakkassa vihāre cīvarakammaṁ karoti.
root_text.mn122:2.9: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena ghaṭāya sakkassa vihāro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.mn122:2.10: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn122:2.11: “sambahulāni kho, ānanda, kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāre senāsanāni paññattāni.
root_text.mn122:2.12: Sambahulā nu kho ettha bhikkhū viharantī”ti?
root_text.mn122:2.13: “Sambahulāni, bhante, kāḷakhemakassa sakkassa vihāre senāsanāni paññattāni.
root_text.mn122:3.1: “Na kho, ānanda, bhikkhu sobhati saṅgaṇikārāmo saṅgaṇikarato saṅgaṇikārāmataṁ anuyutto gaṇārāmo gaṇarato gaṇasammudito.
root_text.mn122:3.2: So vatānanda, bhikkhu saṅgaṇikārāmo saṅgaṇikarato saṅgaṇikārāmataṁ anuyutto gaṇārāmo gaṇarato gaṇasammudito yaṁ taṁ nekkhammasukhaṁ pavivekasukhaṁ upasamasukhaṁ sambodhisukhaṁ tassa sukhassa nikāmalābhī bhavissati akicchalābhī akasiralābhīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn122:3.3: Yo ca kho so, ānanda, bhikkhu eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho viharati tassetaṁ bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṁ yaṁ taṁ nekkhammasukhaṁ pavivekasukhaṁ upasamasukhaṁ sambodhisukhaṁ tassa sukhassa nikāmalābhī bhavissati akicchalābhī akasiralābhīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn122:4.1: So vatānanda, bhikkhu saṅgaṇikārāmo saṅgaṇikarato saṅgaṇikārāmataṁ anuyutto gaṇārāmo gaṇarato gaṇasammudito sāmāyikaṁ vā kantaṁ cetovimuttiṁ upasampajja viharissati asāmāyikaṁ vā akuppanti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn122:4.2: Yo ca kho so, ānanda, bhikkhu eko gaṇasmā vūpakaṭṭho viharati tassetaṁ bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṁ sāmāyikaṁ vā kantaṁ cetovimuttiṁ upasampajja viharissati asāmāyikaṁ vā akuppanti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn122:5.1: Nāhaṁ, ānanda, ekaṁ rūpampi samanupassāmi yattha rattassa yathābhiratassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā.
root_text.mn122:6.1: Ayaṁ kho panānanda, vihāro tathāgatena abhisambuddho yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn122:6.2: sabbanimittānaṁ amanasikārā ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ upasampajja viharituṁ.
root_text.mn122:6.3: Tatra ce, ānanda, tathāgataṁ iminā vihārena viharantaṁ bhavanti upasaṅkamitāro bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo rājāno rājamahāmattā titthiyā titthiyasāvakā.
root_text.mn122:6.4: Tatrānanda, tathāgato vivekaninneneva cittena vivekapoṇena vivekapabbhārena vūpakaṭṭhena nekkhammābhiratena byantībhūtena sabbaso āsavaṭṭhānīyehi dhammehi aññadatthu uyyojanikapaṭisaṁyuttaṁyeva kathaṁ kattā hoti.
root_text.mn122:7.2: ‘ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ upasampajja vihareyyan’ti, tenānanda, bhikkhunā ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapetabbaṁ sannisādetabbaṁ ekodi kātabbaṁ samādahātabbaṁ.
root_text.mn122:7.3: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapeti sannisādeti ekodiṁ karoti samādahati?
root_text.mn122:8.1: Idhānanda, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
root_text.mn122:8.5: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapeti sannisādeti ekodiṁ karoti samādahati.
root_text.mn122:9.2: Tassa ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ manasikaroto suññatāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
root_text.mn122:9.3: Evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:9.4: ‘ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ kho me manasikaroto ajjhattaṁ suññatāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccatī’ti.
root_text.mn122:9.9: Tassa āneñjaṁ manasikaroto āneñjāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
root_text.mn122:9.10: Evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:9.11: ‘āneñjaṁ kho me manasikaroto āneñjāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccatī’ti.
root_text.mn122:10.1: Tenānanda, bhikkhunā tasmiṁyeva purimasmiṁ samādhinimitte ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapetabbaṁ sannisādetabbaṁ ekodi kātabbaṁ samādahātabbaṁ.
root_text.mn122:10.3: Tassa ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ manasikaroto ajjhattaṁ suññatāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
root_text.mn122:10.4: Evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:10.5: ‘ajjhattaṁ suññataṁ kho me manasikaroto ajjhattaṁ suññatāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccatī’ti.
root_text.mn122:10.10: Tassa āneñjaṁ manasikaroto āneñjāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
root_text.mn122:10.11: Evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:10.12: ‘āneñjaṁ kho me manasikaroto āneñjāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccatī’ti.
root_text.mn122:11.1: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato caṅkamāya cittaṁ namati, so caṅkamati:
root_text.mn122:11.2: ‘evaṁ maṁ caṅkamantaṁ nābhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti.
root_text.mn122:11.4: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato ṭhānāya cittaṁ namati, so tiṭṭhati:
root_text.mn122:11.5: ‘evaṁ maṁ ṭhitaṁ nābhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti.
root_text.mn122:11.7: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato nisajjāya cittaṁ namati, so nisīdati:
root_text.mn122:11.8: ‘evaṁ maṁ nisinnaṁ nābhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti.
root_text.mn122:11.10: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato sayanāya cittaṁ namati, so sayati:
root_text.mn122:11.11: ‘evaṁ maṁ sayantaṁ nābhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssavissantī’ti.
root_text.mn122:12.1: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato kathāya cittaṁ namati, so:
root_text.mn122:12.2: ‘yāyaṁ kathā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattati, seyyathidaṁ—rājakathā corakathā mahāmattakathā senākathā bhayakathā yuddhakathā annakathā pānakathā vatthakathā sayanakathā mālākathā gandhakathā ñātikathā yānakathā gāmakathā nigamakathā nagarakathā janapadakathā itthikathā surākathā visikhākathā kumbhaṭṭhānakathā pubbapetakathā nānattakathā lokakkhāyikā samuddakkhāyikā itibhavābhavakathā iti vā iti—evarūpiṁ kathaṁ na kathessāmī’ti.
root_text.mn122:12.4: Yā ca kho ayaṁ, ānanda, kathā abhisallekhikā cetovinīvaraṇasappāyā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, seyyathidaṁ—appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṁsaggakathā vīriyārambhakathā sīlakathā samādhikathā paññākathā vimuttikathā vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā iti: ‘evarūpiṁ kathaṁ kathessāmī’ti.
root_text.mn122:13.1: Tassa ce, ānanda, bhikkhuno iminā vihārena viharato vitakkāya cittaṁ namati, so:
root_text.mn122:13.2: ‘ye te vitakkā hīnā gammā pothujjanikā anariyā anatthasaṁhitā na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti, seyyathidaṁ—kāmavitakko byāpādavitakko vihiṁsāvitakko iti evarūpe vitakke na vitakkessāmī’ti.
root_text.mn122:13.4: Ye ca kho ime, ānanda, vitakkā ariyā niyyānikā niyyanti takkarassa sammādukkhakkhayāya, seyyathidaṁ—nekkhammavitakko abyāpādavitakko avihiṁsāvitakko iti: ‘evarūpe vitakke vitakkessāmī’ti.
root_text.mn122:14.3: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,
root_text.mn122:14.7: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
root_text.mn122:15.1: Yattha bhikkhunā abhikkhaṇaṁ sakaṁ cittaṁ paccavekkhitabbaṁ:
root_text.mn122:15.2: ‘atthi nu kho me imesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu aññatarasmiṁ vā aññatarasmiṁ vā āyatane uppajjati cetaso samudācāro’ti?
root_text.mn122:15.3: Sace, ānanda, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:15.4: ‘atthi kho me imesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu aññatarasmiṁ vā aññatarasmiṁ vā āyatane uppajjati cetaso samudācāro’ti,
root_text.mn122:15.5: evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:15.6: ‘yo kho imesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chandarāgo so me nappahīno’ti.
root_text.mn122:15.8: Sace panānanda, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:15.9: ‘natthi kho me imesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu aññatarasmiṁ vā aññatarasmiṁ vā āyatane uppajjati cetaso samudācāro’ti,
root_text.mn122:15.10: evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:15.11: ‘yo kho imesu pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chandarāgo so me pahīno’ti.
root_text.mn122:16.1: Pañca kho ime, ānanda, upādānakkhandhā yattha bhikkhunā udayabbayānupassinā vihātabbaṁ:
root_text.mn122:16.2: ‘iti rūpaṁ iti rūpassa samudayo iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo,
root_text.mn122:16.6: iti viññāṇaṁ iti viññāṇassa samudayo iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo’ti.
root_text.mn122:17.1: Tassa imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino viharato yo pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu asmimāno so pahīyati.
root_text.mn122:17.2: Evaṁ santametaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ pajānāti:
root_text.mn122:17.3: ‘yo kho imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu asmimāno so me pahīno’ti.
root_text.mn122:18.1: Ime kho te, ānanda, dhammā ekantakusalā kusalāyātikā ariyā lokuttarā anavakkantā pāpimatā.
root_text.mn122:19.2: kaṁ atthavasaṁ sampassamāno arahati sāvako satthāraṁ anubandhituṁ api paṇujjamāno”ti?
root_text.mn122:19.3: “Bhagavaṁmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṁnettikā bhagavaṁpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.mn122:20.1: “Na kho, ānanda, arahati sāvako satthāraṁ anubandhituṁ, yadidaṁ suttaṁ geyyaṁ veyyākaraṇaṁ tassa hetu.
root_text.mn122:20.3: Dīgharattassa hi te, ānanda, dhammā sutā dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
root_text.mn122:20.4: Yā ca kho ayaṁ, ānanda, kathā abhisallekhikā cetovinīvaraṇasappāyā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattati, seyyathidaṁ—appicchakathā santuṭṭhikathā pavivekakathā asaṁsaggakathā vīriyārambhakathā sīlakathā samādhikathā paññākathā vimuttikathā vimuttiñāṇadassanakathā—evarūpiyā kho, ānanda, kathāya hetu arahati sāvako satthāraṁ anubandhituṁ api paṇujjamāno.
root_text.mn122:21.1: Evaṁ sante kho, ānanda, ācariyūpaddavo hoti, evaṁ sante antevāsūpaddavo hoti, evaṁ sante brahmacārūpaddavo hoti.
root_text.mn122:22.2: Idhānanda, ekacco satthā vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn122:22.3: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato anvāvattanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
root_text.mn122:22.4: So anvāvattantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca mucchaṁ nikāmayati, gedhaṁ āpajjati, āvattati bāhullāya.
root_text.mn122:22.6: Ācariyūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn122:23.2: Tasseva kho panānanda, satthu sāvako tassa satthu vivekamanubrūhayamāno
root_text.mn122:23.3: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn122:23.4: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato anvāvattanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
root_text.mn122:23.5: So anvāvattantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca mucchaṁ nikāmayati, gedhaṁ āpajjati, āvattati bāhullāya.
root_text.mn122:23.7: Antevāsūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn122:24.2: Idhānanda, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn122:24.3: So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn122:24.4: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato anvāvattanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
root_text.mn122:24.5: So anvāvattantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca na mucchaṁ nikāmayati, na gedhaṁ āpajjati, na āvattati bāhullāya.
root_text.mn122:24.6: Tasseva kho panānanda, satthu sāvako tassa satthu vivekamanubrūhayamāno
root_text.mn122:24.7: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn122:24.8: Tassa tathāvūpakaṭṭhassa viharato anvāvattanti brāhmaṇagahapatikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca.
root_text.mn122:24.9: So anvāvattantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamesu ceva jānapadesu ca mucchaṁ nikāmayati, gedhaṁ āpajjati, āvattati bāhullāya.
root_text.mn122:24.11: Brahmacārūpaddavena avadhiṁsu naṁ pāpakā akusalā dhammā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṁ jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn122:24.13: Tatrānanda, yo cevāyaṁ ācariyūpaddavo, yo ca antevāsūpaddavo ayaṁ tehi brahmacārūpaddavo dukkhavipākataro ceva kaṭukavipākataro ca, api ca vinipātāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn122:25.1: Tasmātiha maṁ, ānanda, mittavatāya samudācaratha, mā sapattavatāya.
root_text.mn122:25.2: Taṁ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn122:25.3: Kathañcānanda, satthāraṁ sāvakā sapattavatāya samudācaranti, no mittavatāya?
root_text.mn122:25.4: Idhānanda, satthā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṁ upādāya:
root_text.mn122:25.6: Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṁ odahanti, na aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.mn122:25.7: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, satthāraṁ sāvakā sapattavatāya samudācaranti, no mittavatāya.
root_text.mn122:26.1: Kathañcānanda, satthāraṁ sāvakā mittavatāya samudācaranti, no sapattavatāya?
root_text.mn122:26.2: Idhānanda, satthā sāvakānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṁ upādāya:
root_text.mn122:26.4: Tassa sāvakā sussūsanti, sotaṁ odahanti, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhapenti, na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti.
root_text.mn122:26.5: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, satthāraṁ sāvakā mittavatāya samudācaranti, no sapattavatāya.
root_text.mn122:26.6: Tasmātiha maṁ, ānanda, mittavatāya samudācaratha, mā sapattavatāya.
root_text.mn122:26.7: Taṁ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn122:27.1: Na vo ahaṁ, ānanda, tathā parakkamissāmi yathā kumbhakāro āmake āmakamatte.
root_text.mn122:27.6: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn122:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
translation_text.mn122:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
translation_text.mn122:2.2: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the lodge of the Sakyan Khemaka the Dark for the day’s meditation.
translation_text.mn122:2.3: Now at that time many resting places had been spread out at the lodge of Khemaka the Dark.
translation_text.mn122:2.6: “Many resting places have been spread out;
translation_text.mn122:2.7: are there many mendicants living here?”
translation_text.mn122:2.8: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda, together with many other mendicants, was making robes at the lodge of the Sakyan Ghaṭā.
translation_text.mn122:2.9: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ghaṭā’s lodge, where he sat on the seat spread out
translation_text.mn122:2.11: “Many resting places have been spread out at the lodge of Khemaka the Dark;
translation_text.mn122:2.15: It’s currently the time for making robes.”
translation_text.mn122:3.1: “Ānanda, a mendicant doesn’t shine who enjoys company and groups, who loves them and likes to enjoy them.
translation_text.mn122:3.2: It is quite impossible that such a mendicant will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
translation_text.mn122:3.3: But you should expect that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group, will get the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is possible.
translation_text.mn122:4.1: Indeed, Ānanda, it is quite impossible that a mendicant who enjoys company will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
translation_text.mn122:4.2: But it is possible that a mendicant who lives alone, withdrawn from the group will enter and remain in the freedom of heart—either that which is temporary and pleasant, or that which is irreversible and unshakable.
translation_text.mn122:5.1: Ānanda, I do not see even a single sight which, with its decay and perishing, would not give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in someone who has desire and lust for it.
translation_text.mn122:6.1: But this meditation has been understood by the Realized One, namely
translation_text.mn122:6.2: to enter and remain in emptiness internally by not focusing on any signs.
translation_text.mn122:6.3: Now, suppose that while the Realized One is practicing this meditation, monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, rulers and their chief ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples go to visit him.
translation_text.mn122:6.4: In that case, with a mind slanting, sloping, and inclining to seclusion, withdrawn, and loving renunciation, having totally eliminated defiling influences, he invariably gives a talk concerned only with sending them away.
translation_text.mn122:7.1: Therefore, if a mendicant should wish,
translation_text.mn122:7.2: ‘May I enter and remain in emptiness internally!’ then they should still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally.
translation_text.mn122:7.3: And how does a mendicant still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally?
translation_text.mn122:8.1: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …
translation_text.mn122:8.5: That’s how a mendicant stills, settles, unifies, and immerses their mind in samādhi internally.
translation_text.mn122:9.2: but their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.
translation_text.mn122:9.4: ‘I am focusing on emptiness internally, but my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.’
translation_text.mn122:9.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:9.7: They focus on emptiness internally and externally …
translation_text.mn122:9.9: but their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.
translation_text.mn122:9.11: ‘I am focusing on the imperturbable internally, but my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.’
translation_text.mn122:9.12: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:10.1: Then that mendicant should still, settle, unify, and immerse their mind in samādhi internally using the same meditation subject as a basis of immersion that they used before.
translation_text.mn122:10.3: and their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.
translation_text.mn122:10.5: ‘I am focusing on emptiness internally, and my mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.’
translation_text.mn122:10.6: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:10.8: They focus on emptiness internally and externally …
translation_text.mn122:10.10: and their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.
translation_text.mn122:10.12: ‘I am focusing on the imperturbable, and my mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.’
translation_text.mn122:10.13: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:11.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to walking, they walk, thinking:
translation_text.mn122:11.2: ‘While I’m walking, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
translation_text.mn122:11.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:11.4: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to standing, they stand, thinking:
translation_text.mn122:11.5: ‘While I’m standing, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
translation_text.mn122:11.6: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:11.7: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to sitting, they sit, thinking:
translation_text.mn122:11.8: ‘While I’m sitting, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
translation_text.mn122:11.9: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:11.10: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to lying down, they lie down, thinking:
translation_text.mn122:11.11: ‘While I’m lying down, bad, unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure will not overwhelm me.’
translation_text.mn122:11.12: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:12.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to talking, they think:
translation_text.mn122:12.2: ‘I will not engage in the kind of speech that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such speech doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. Namely: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.’
translation_text.mn122:12.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:12.4: ‘But I will take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.’
translation_text.mn122:12.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:13.1: While a mendicant is practicing such a meditation, if their mind inclines to thinking, they think:
translation_text.mn122:13.2: ‘I will not think the kind of thought that is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. Such thoughts don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.’
translation_text.mn122:13.3: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:13.4: ‘But I will think the kind of thought that is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. That is, thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.’
translation_text.mn122:13.5: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:14.1: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn122:14.3: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn122:14.7: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn122:14.8: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn122:15.1: So a mendicant should regularly check their own mind:
translation_text.mn122:15.2: ‘Does my mind take an interest in any of these five kinds of sensual stimulation?’
translation_text.mn122:15.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
translation_text.mn122:15.6: ‘I have not given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
translation_text.mn122:15.7: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:15.8: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows this:
translation_text.mn122:15.9: ‘My mind does not take an interest.’
translation_text.mn122:15.11: ‘I have given up desire and greed for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.’
translation_text.mn122:15.12: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:16.1: A mendicant should meditate observing rise and fall in these five grasping aggregates:
translation_text.mn122:16.2: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
translation_text.mn122:16.6: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
translation_text.mn122:17.1: As they do so, they give up the conceit ‘I am’ regarding the five grasping aggregates.
translation_text.mn122:17.3: ‘I have given up the conceit “I am” regarding the five grasping aggregates.’
translation_text.mn122:17.4: In this way they are aware of the situation.
translation_text.mn122:18.1: These principles are entirely skillful, with skillful outcomes; they are noble, transcendent, and inaccessible to the Wicked One.
translation_text.mn122:19.2: For what reason would a disciple deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher, even if driven away?”
translation_text.mn122:19.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn122:20.1: “A disciple would not deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher for the sake of this, namely statements, mixed prose & verse, or discussions.
translation_text.mn122:20.3: Because for a long time you have learned the teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
translation_text.mn122:20.4: But a disciple would deem it worthwhile to follow the Teacher, even if driven away, for the sake of talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart and leads solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
translation_text.mn122:21.1: This being so, Ānanda, there is a peril for the tutor, a peril for the pupil, and a peril for a spiritual practitioner.
translation_text.mn122:22.1: And how is there a peril for the tutor?
translation_text.mn122:22.2: It’s when some teacher frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn122:22.3: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn122:22.4: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
translation_text.mn122:22.5: This is said to be the tutor’s peril.
translation_text.mn122:22.6: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn122:22.7: That’s how there is a peril for the tutor.
translation_text.mn122:23.1: And how is there a peril for the pupil?
translation_text.mn122:23.2: It’s when the disciple of a teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
translation_text.mn122:23.3: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn122:23.4: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn122:23.5: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
translation_text.mn122:23.6: This is said to be the pupil’s peril.
translation_text.mn122:23.7: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn122:23.8: That’s how there is a peril for the pupil.
translation_text.mn122:24.1: And how is there a peril for a spiritual practitioner?
translation_text.mn122:24.2: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn122:24.3: He frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn122:24.4: While meditating withdrawn, he’s visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn122:24.5: When this happens, he doesn’t enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
translation_text.mn122:24.6: But a disciple of this teacher, emulating their teacher’s fostering of seclusion,
translation_text.mn122:24.7: frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn122:24.8: While meditating withdrawn, they’re visited by a stream of brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
translation_text.mn122:24.9: When this happens, they enjoy infatuation, fall into greed, and return to indulgence.
translation_text.mn122:24.10: This is said to be the spiritual practitioner’s peril.
translation_text.mn122:24.11: They’re ruined by bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn122:24.12: That’s how there is a peril for the spiritual practitioner.
translation_text.mn122:24.13: And in this context, Ānanda, as compared to the peril of the tutor or the pupil, the peril of the spiritual practitioner has more painful, bitter results, and even leads to the underworld.
translation_text.mn122:25.1: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
translation_text.mn122:25.2: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn122:25.3: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend?
translation_text.mn122:25.4: It’s when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:
translation_text.mn122:25.5: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
translation_text.mn122:25.6: But their disciples don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.mn122:25.7: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as an enemy, not a friend.
translation_text.mn122:26.1: And how do disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy?
translation_text.mn122:26.2: It’s when the Teacher teaches Dhamma to his disciples out of kindness and sympathy:
translation_text.mn122:26.3: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’
translation_text.mn122:26.4: And their disciples want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.
translation_text.mn122:26.5: That’s how the disciples treat their Teacher as a friend, not an enemy.
translation_text.mn122:26.6: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
translation_text.mn122:26.7: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn122:27.1: I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots.
translation_text.mn122:27.2: I shall speak, correcting you again and again,
translation_text.mn122:27.4: The core will stand the test.”
translation_text.mn122:27.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn122:27.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
